subject: Re: [junit] Parameterized test case pattern
msgSnippet: ... Not sure what this has to do with my question. Which was:  depending on whether you create your tests yourself or you let JUnit create them, you need to
messageBody:
On 11/14/05, Eugene Kuleshov <eu@...> wrote:
>
> Cédric Beust ♔ wrote:
>
> >> Justification? This is just how JUnit resolve test cases.
> >>
> >>
> >I mean: how come the test fails if you fail to call the super
> constructor
> >with a string?
> >
> >It's so counterintuitive that it tripped even Elliotte... (and myself
> many
> >times).
> >
> >
> Was it you who said that he always using assertNull(value) without a
> description?


Not sure what this has to do with my question.

Which was: depending on whether you create your tests yourself or you let
JUnit create them, you need to call super(String) or super().

Why?

And a side question: if you use the parameterized test pattern, it's okay
to do your initialization in the constructor, whereas setUp() is usually the
recommended place in the other cases.

--
Cédric


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
